numbered_ace_sentences: 1. Some students have the same test scores.
2. Colleges must decide which student to admit to an elite college.
3. A legacy applicant has a better chance of admission than a non-legacy applicant.
4. Money is another factor in admission decisions.
5. Some non-legacy applicants come from poor families.
6. Some non-legacy applicants come from wealthy families.
7. A non-legacy applicant from a poor family has a higher chance of admission than a wealthy non-legacy applicant.
8. This trend appears in the data.
9. A person in the top 0.1% is 7 times more likely to be admitted than a person with similar attributes and without legacy status.
10. I wonder why colleges pay more attention to a student's background and income than to a student's test scores.
11. Assume that a non-legacy student has a higher test score than a legacy student.
12. I ask whether this higher test score convinces colleges to admit the non-legacy student instead of the legacy student.
13. I am a high school student.
14. My community includes high school students.
15. We prepare to enter college.
16. We pursue careers.
17. People of my age or older must consider these admission details.
18. We must be aware of our possibilities.
19. We must take advantage of what we can.
20. The headline is: Legacy status is the leeway to college.
21. The headline is: How is this fair to others.
22. The headline is: Wealthy in knowledge or wealthy in reputation.
